similar_project_experience.project_name: Readiness Center
similar_project_experience.project_description: Civil Engineer. Jared provided civil design for the Theater Aviation Sustainment Maintenance Group Readiness Center. He designed grading, drainage, pavement (adequate parking, access drives and runway aprons), a stormwater control system, new utilities, landscaped walkways, and AT/FP measures. Site civil design followed UFC 3-201-01 Civil Engineering and UFC 1-200-01 DoD Building Code. Jared worked with owner to apply value engineering concepts to maximize use of the limited space for the new military facility and incorporate design traits that were unique to readiness centers including designing blast protection due to the facility's proximity to the parking lot, using permeable concrete to reduce heat island effect, and installing extra energy efficient vehicle parking and charging stations. His design met LEED Silver Certification and sustainable design requirements per UFC 1-200-02. He assisted the contractor in applying for a FAA 7460 Permit including restrictions for cranes in the airspace. His design included required setbacks, and proper blast protection and courtyard protection within the 90-foot radius to the parking lot, complying with UFC 4-010-01 Minimum AT/FP Standards for Buildings. All civil design reviews were completed using DrChecks. Jared prepared a cost estimate for the site/civil project features, ensuring that the design was financially feasible and within budget constraints. Size: 89,000 SF | Cost: $1.6M (Design), $22.0M (Construction)

similar_project_experience.project_name: Replacement Hospital
similar_project_experience.project_description: Civil Engineer. Jared was the lead civil designer for this new hospital. Scope included a hospital building, health clinic, ambulance garage, central utility plant, helipad, and emergency power. He designed site grading, stormwater management systems, vehicular access improvements, and utilities. Jared completed grading, cut and fill, and slope calculations, and designed a stepped building to accommodate the site's significant topographic relief. His design applied value engineering concepts and was crucial in maximizing the development area while minimizing the amount of earthwork required. He also managed the distribution of domestic water (following UFC 3-230-01 Water Storage and Distribution) and fire protection systems (following UFC 3-600-01 Fire Protection Engineering for Facilities) as well as improvements to the sanitary sewer system (following UFC 3-240-01 Wastewater Collection). Site/civil design followed UFC 3-201-01 Civil Engineering and UFC 1-200-01 DoD Building Code. He conducted a stormwater study to evaluate site runoff including runoff calculations to determine volume of stormwater. This study was essential for compliance with the Energy Independence and Security Act, which mandates that a site retain runoff from the 95th percentile rain event to the maximum extent feasible. Jared addressed this with design of a stormwater extended detention and underdrain system, which reduced peak discharge and improved water quality. He implemented a SWPPP following UFC 1-200-02. He designed erosion control measures that prevented erosion during and after construction. He prepared a cost estimate for civil features, ensuring the design was financially feasible and within budget constraints. Size: 445,332 SF | Cost: $2.3M (Design), $305.0M est. (Construction)

similar_project_experience.project_name: F-35 Apron Replacement
similar_project_experience.project_description: Jon led the planning and civil engineering of an aviation apron replacement project. The project is divided into two phases: the study phase, and the design phase. The study phase included in depth review and analysis of the existing stormwater system and site information. He led a team on-site to investigate the source of subsurface groundwater that was leading to the deterioration of the concrete apron. Through hydraulic modeling, his analysis determined the existing stormwater system was undersized and faulty, exacerbating the poor paving conditions. Jon led the civil engineering design of the F-35 Apron Replacement, performing engineering studies, hydraulic modeling, design, and preparation of preliminary and final design drawings and specifications. As part of the preliminary engineering, Jon conducted pre-design site assessments and design charette meetings with USAF and NAVFAC staff. Construction was complete in 2022. Challenges/Successes: Resiliency to storms and large stormwater flows is crucial to the success of any aviation project. Poor record drawings, sealed drainage structures, and years of apron pavement buildup provided a difficult task to assess the source of ongoing pavement damage. Jon developed several design packages and worked closely with the contractor to limit pavement and utility removals, ultimately delivering a cost-efficient project on schedule. | Size: 14 Acres | Cost: $10M | Role: Civil Engineer

similar_project_experience.project_name: Camp Gruber Unit Training Equipment Site (UTES) Renovation
similar_project_experience.project_description: Nic provided survey services for the Camp Gruber Unit Training Equipment Site (UTES) renovation. This included the renovation of an existing administrative area, renovations of the existing shop bays, and addition for new shop bays and support offices. The existing building was supported on drilled shafts terminating in bedrock at the site, and to reduce the potential for differential settlement between the new additions and the existing facility, which was to be left in place, drilled shafts were desired by the structural and civil designer. UFC criteria were followed during the investigation and analysis of the facility, from foundation design to pavement thickness and subgrade preparation for the anticipated vehicle traffic of the tanks and large transport vehicles at the site. Construction is estimated to be complete in 2021.

similar_project_experience.project_name: Kitchen Design and Wastewater Treatment Plant Improvements
similar_project_experience.project_description: Nic performed survey services for the Design-Build renovation for the Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) at the Port Isabel Detention Center. Improvements included replacement of the headworks, pump house, and influent wet well submersible pumps. Olsson was responsible for the engineering design for the WWTP improvements including the WWTP process, site civil, structural, and electrical design, including Instrumentation and controls (I&C;), as well as some mechanical and plumbing design. Also performed a topographical survey of the site, including provision for locations for above-grade structures, utility locations (based on available maps field observations), inverts on manholes, and other critical items and all structural design. The existing WWTP remained operational as improvements were implemented.
